title: NEXUS Criteria for C-Spine Imaging
description: Clinically clears cervical spine fracture without imaging in alert, stable trauma patients. The NEXUS (National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study) criteria help determine which blunt trauma patients do not require cervical spine imaging.

parameters.name: midline_cervical_tenderness
parameters.description: Midline posterior bony cervical spine tenderness on palpation from nuchal ridge to first thoracic vertebra

parameters.name: focal_neurologic_deficit
parameters.description: Any focal neurologic deficit (weakness, numbness, or sensory changes)

parameters.name: altered_alertness
parameters.description: Normal alertness and level of consciousness (alert, oriented, cooperative)

parameters.name: intoxication
parameters.description: Evidence of intoxication (alcohol, drugs, or other substances)

parameters.name: distracting_injury
parameters.description: Painful distracting injury that may impair the reliability of the physical examination

result.name: imaging_recommendation
result.description: Recommendation for cervical spine imaging based on NEXUS criteria

ranges.interpretation: Patient meets all five NEXUS criteria and is at low risk for cervical spine injury. Cervical spine imaging can be safely avoided. Sensitivity 99.6% for detecting clinically significant cervical spine injuries.
Patient does not meet all NEXUS criteria. Cervical spine imaging (CT scan preferred) is recommended to rule out cervical spine injury. Clinical assessment alone is insufficient to exclude injury.

references: Hoffman JR, Mower WR, Wolfson AB, Todd KH, Zucker MI. Validity of a set of clinical criteria to rule out injury to the cervical spine in patients with blunt trauma. N Engl J Med. 2000;343(2):94-99. doi:10.1056/NEJM200007133430203
Stiell IG, Wells GA, Vandemheen KL, et al. The Canadian C-spine rule versus the NEXUS low-risk criteria in patients with trauma. N Engl J Med. 2003;349(26):2510-2518. doi:10.1056/NEJMoa031375

Paykin G, O'Reilly G, Ackland HM, Mitra B. The NEXUS criteria are insufficient to exclude cervical spine fractures in older blunt trauma patients. Injury. 2017;48(5):1020-1024. doi:10.1016/j.injury.2017.02.013
formula: All five criteria must be met for low risk classification: (1) No midline cervical tenderness AND (2) No focal neurologic deficit AND (3) Normal alertness AND (4) No intoxication AND (5) No painful distracting injury
notes: Validated in blunt trauma patients only
Less reliable in patients >65 years of age
Use caution in pediatric patients (<18 years)
Canadian C-Spine Rule may be more sensitive
Mnemonic: NSAID (Neurologic deficit absent, Spinal tenderness absent, Alertness normal, Intoxication absent, Distracting injury absent)
